) Program Owner: Program Manager - Employment Tax Policy. The mission Employment Tax Policy is to establish effective policies and procedures to support compliance with employment tax laws. (

) SB/SE Employment Tax Workload Selection and Delivery (ET-WSD) has primary responsibility for workload identiﬁcation for Employment Tax. ﬁeld examiners must be continuously aware of new developments, rulings, decisions affecting industries within their jurisdictions. Field Examination is couraged to forward suggestions for Preparer Projects, Compliance Initiative Projects (CIPs) and partnering opportunities to ET-WSD at “*SBSE ET WSD Referrals”. (

) There are various sources that assist in detecting taxpayers who are not complying with the employment tax laws. These sources include: a. Internal Revenue Service employees who are in constant contact with taxpayers and are aware of possible non-compliance. Employment tax managers and examiners may receive referrals from Collection, Assistance Centers, Criminal Investigation, Examination, Automated lection System (ACS) call sites, and Campus. Leads received from sources must be forwarded to ET-WSD for evaluation and selection audit, if warranted. Note: Specialist Referral System (SRS) referrals submitted to the ment Tax Program for immediate assistance by an Employment Specialist will be evaluated and assigned by the group manager. These are not forwarded to ET-WSD unless the case cannot be worked immediately or the referral is not made on a case open for an income tax examination.

WSD unless the case cannot be worked immediately or the referral is not made on a case open for an income tax examination. b. Other federal and state government agencies (Social Security tion, Department of Labor, State Departments of Unemployment, etc.), c. Market segment studies, and d. Compliance initiatives. Strong emphasis is placed on the required ﬁling

check program. During an amination of an income tax, excise tax, or exempt organization return, the examiner will follow the established procedures to determine if the taxpayer in compliance with employment tax ﬁling requirements and will decide if an amination of employment tax returns is warranted. If warranted, it should be conducted concurrently with the primary examination. If a concurrent tion is not possible, an employment tax referral should be made. Related return information must be considered when determining potential for employment tax returns. This includes a review of the related income tax returns and, in the case of large corporations or publicly traded companies, a review of ﬁnancial statements. Information may also be from news articles, company publications, and internet searches, such as curities and Exchange Commission (SEC) ﬁlings and company websites.

) All income tax cases selected for examination under the LB&I program include consideration of employment tax potential. For a listing of mandatory referrals in the Specialist Referral System, see: https://organization.dstest. (

) The request for a specialist is made using the SRS at: SRS can be used by any employee, regardless of operating division. In addi- tion to requesting assistance, SRS may be used to submit informal or to request a consultation with an employment tax specialist to discuss ployment tax potential in the case. (
) The assistance of an employment tax specialist may be sought regardless of whether the team audit concept is employed in the particular case. (

) The Employment Tax Program may receive referrals from Criminal Investiga- tion (CI). These lead cases should be worked with continual awareness of fraud potential. If indications of fraud are developed during the examination, the case should be discussed with the group manager and Fraud Advisor (FEA) to determine if a fraud referral to CI is warranted. (
) In SB/SE, classiﬁcation and selection of employment tax returns for tion is the responsibility of ET-WSD. Selection (

) ET-WSD conducts the initial review of leads to determine employment tax SB/SE potential. Generally, leads have been identiﬁed as part of a project, identiﬁed Tax workstream, or referral. In most situations, the case ﬁle is pre-built with IDRS research, a classiﬁcation sheet, and any other appropriate data. (
) All employment tax projects and workstreams are designed to identify cases with high potential for audit. Identiﬁcation is generally achieved by sorting ﬁltering data. (
) The following subsections include examples of the types of work classiﬁed selected by ET-WSD. The list is not all-inclusive. (

) The Backup Withholding (BWH) program provides notices to payers who ﬁle information returns with incorrect payee Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Numbers (TINs). The Computer Paragraph (CP)
Notice (CP
) advises that backup withholding could become necessary if a payee fails to certify or validate their TIN. The CP

instructs the payer to provide a “B” Notice to each payee whose Name/TIN combination and account number are as incorrect by the IRS. The “B” Notice informs the payee that the combination furnished to the payer does not match IRS or SSA records and describes the steps the payee must take to avoid backup withholding. (
) The CP
Notice also lists payee accounts with missing TINs on which payer was required to backup withhold under IRC
)(A). Payers missing or obviously incorrect TIN accounts should not wait to receive a CP
to begin backup withholding. The BWH program includes a number different information returns, including but not limited to: • Form
-INT, Interest Income, • Form
-MISC, Miscellaneous Information (formerly, Miscellaneous Income), and • Form
-K, Payment Card and Third Party Network Transactions. (
) Payers with payees receiving Form
-MISC with missing or obviously incorrect TINs have the highest audit potential; backup withholding on ing amounts should have been withheld at the time of payment. (

) The Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (CSP) allows businesses and tax examiners to resolve worker classiﬁcation cases without involving an appeal, thereby reducing taxpayer burden. The procedures ensure that the taxpayer relief provisions under section
of the Revenue Act of
are properly applied. Under the CSP, examiners are able to offer businesses under nation a worker classiﬁcation settlement using a standard closing agreement. See IRM
, CSP Standard Closing Agreement. (

) Monitoring and follow-up activities are centralized in the ET-WSD for agree- ments secured in SB/SE and Appeals; TE/GE will monitor its own Since CSP closing agreements include a provision that the taxpayer prospectively, research using Corporate Files On-Line (CFOL) command will ensure that taxpayers are in compliance with their agreement. See IRM
, Monitoring CSP Agreements. (
) Taxpayers not in compliance with CSP closing agreements have a high classiﬁcation audit potential. See IRM
, Employment Tax - Settlement Program (CSP), for additional information. (

) Under a Voluntary Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (VCSP) closing agreement, businesses not under examination can apply for a worker cation settlement using a standard closing agreement. Monitoring and follow-up activities for SB/SE and LB&I will be centralized in the ET-WSD; TE/GE will monitor its own agreements. Because the VCSP closing includes a provision that requires the taxpayer to comply prospectively, research using CFOL command codes will ensure that taxpayers are in ance with the VCSP closing agreements. See IRM
, Employment Tax Voluntary Classiﬁcation Settlement Program (VCSP) Procedures, for information. (

) Some lead-driven initiatives require an approved Compliance Initiative (CIP). CIPs involve groups of taxpayers characterized by unique employment tax compliance issues. All employment tax specialists are encouraged to identify areas where CIP procedures can assist in identifying employment tax non-compliance. Any suggestions should be discussed with the manager before contacting Employment Tax Policy to discuss the issue and determine development of a CIP is appropriate. (
) The criteria mentioned in IRM
, Purpose and Scope, must be used determine when CIP procedures apply for Employment Tax projects. (
) CIP procedures are not required in the case of “routine business operations,” as deﬁned in IRM
, Activities Not Subject to CIP Procedures.

) ET-WSD has the primary responsibility for reviewing leads received from sources other than SRS and making a determination on whether the case Leads be selected for examination or rejected for lack of potential. Group and examiners receiving referrals from sources other than the SRS will these referrals to ET-WSD via the electronic mailbox “*SBSE ET WSD Referrals” for consideration. (

) Employment Tax Examination group managers receive all Specialist Referral System (SRS) referrals for their area of coverage. Group managers will that the referrals received are given appropriate consideration, consistent available staffing and resources. Compliance efforts and follow-up actions also be determined in accordance with resource availability. If the receiving group manager cannot work the case due to resource issues, consideration must be given to transferring the case to a different employment tax group work. Non-compliance with tax laws within the geographic area should be sidered when determining if a transfer is warranted. (

) Often, the selection of an LB&I employment tax return for examination is initiated from a referral generated at the start of a related income tax for tion. ) In certain situations, employment tax leads may be assigned directly to the examiner to determine if a compliance check should be conducted rather an examination. (
) A compliance check is a review conducted under Title

of the IRC to determine whether a business owner or individual is adhering to record keeping and information reporting requirements. It does not directly relate to the determination of a tax liability for any particular period. (
) A compliance check should be considered as an opportunity to educate the taxpayer and encourage compliance. Pub
, Compliance Checks, additional information on compliance checks and is used as a taxpayer handout. (

) Compliance checks can be useful tools in certain situations. However, care must be exercised to prevent examining the taxpayer under the guise of a compliance check to avoid infringing on taxpayer rights and to also avoid tablishing a section

safe haven. Note: Generally, SB/SE Employment Tax does not conduct compliance checks, uses examinations to determine adherence to information and reporting quirements. Managerial approval must be secured by an examiner to conduct a compliance check.
Note: For information on tip compliance checks, see IRM 4.23.7.12, Compliance Follow up Reviews on Voluntary Tip Agreements.

(b) or as an audit for purposes of section

of the Revenue Act of To avoid unauthorized disclosures of return information, immediately identify the taxpayer or his/her authorized representative. Employment Tax - Examination Programs and Examination Planning Procedures 4.23.3
Under IRC

, the taxpayer has a right to: a. Receive, in non-technical language, an explanation of the rights available at each step of the examination process. This explanation must be furnished before an initial interview. Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, was developed to meet this requirement. Routine telephone calls initiated by the taxpayer or the Service are not considered initial interviews. Pub

explains the procedures covering examination of tax returns and appeal rights and should be furnished to all taxpayers. Examiners must ensure the taxpayer has a full understanding of the examination process. First, at the beginning of an examination, ask the taxpayer whether they have any questions regarding the audit process, regular selection procedures, or appeal rights. Second, if the taxpayer does have questions, give clear and concise explanations. Third, advise the taxpayer of various court remedies available for employment tax issues: All post-assessment em- ployment tax cases can be heard in a U.S. District Court or the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. Some employment tax cases can be heard by the U.S. Tax Court before assessment is made if they involve IRC
issues. b. Consult with a representative who is currently authorized to represent taxpayers under rules provided in Treasury Department Circular

, “Regulations Governing the Practice of Attorneys, Certiﬁed Public Ac- countants, Enrolled Agents, Enrolled Actuaries, Enrolled Retirement Plan Agents and Appraisers before the Internal Revenue Service”. If taxpayers clearly state, during an interview, that they wish to consult with a repre- sentative, suspend the interview until the representative is involved. In cases where this process is abused (e.g., repeated suspension of inter- views to contact a representative) an administrative summons may be issued. A taxpayer cannot be required to accompany an authorized sentative to an examination interview in the absence of an administrative summons. However, the taxpayer’s voluntary presence at the interview can be requested through the representative as a means to expedite the process. c. Notice

The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS. TAS helps taxpayers whose problems with the IRS are causing ﬁnancial difficulties; who have tried but have not been able to resolve their problems with the IRS; and those who believe an IRS system or procedure is not working as it should.
